name: Database Games-Computer
keyboard: Two controllers with 12 buttons, 2 fire buttons and an analog joystick
graphics: Yes, 4 single colour sprites (1 can be 8 colours)
description:
This obscure videogame system was made by Voltmace, a British company based in Baldock. Voltmace came into being in 1977 as a pure sales/marketing organisation - it offered sales facilities to companies who had a product to sell. They were contracted by one of the early pionneers in the video field to handle their product.

Shortly after this, Voltmace came into contact with Teleng who were putting out one of the first programmable machines and there ensued a short but profitable association during which Voltmace sold many of the British made game machines. But later Teleng's parent company decided to close down the factory in Essex and gradually run down video game production in the U.K.

Eventually, in 1980 Voltmace approached the Videomaster arm of the Waddington's company with a view to marketing their Database game machine - which was at the time being made in Hong Kong.

Their first season with the Database was quite successful and when, in early '81, the chance came to purchase the machine in its entirety, Voltmace jumped at the chance.

They could at last produce a British made video games machine in their Baldock factory and it was quickly arranged for all the tooling machinery to be shipped over from Hong Kong - by June '81 all the hardware needed was in Baldock and staff were recruited to start production.

One of the drawbacks of the Database machine when it was being made in Hong Kong was a certain reputation for unreliability. Voltmace tried to resolve that by strict quality-control and good after-sales service. But the Database couldn't resist long enough against competitors like Atari, Intellivision and Colecovision, and the '83 videogame industry crash surely doomed the Voltmace adventure...

The other noteworthy Voltmace products were joysticks for popular micro-computers, mainly BBC systems. There were in fact Database controllers modified to be used with other systems.

In fact the Database is software compatible with the Interton VC-4000 and "clones". This doesn't mean that it can use the Interton cartridges, as they won't fit, but the internal specs and software are the same. The CPU is the 2650A from Signetics and the Video Controller is the 2636 from Signetics as well.

About 40 cartridges has been released for the Interton VC-4000, but only 29 were available for the Database... It seems that a converter was available to play Interton cartridges on a Voltmace Database! Surprisingly, original games for the Database were programmed by Derek Andrews at the time : Leap-Frog, Crunch and a Defender clone (never released). See Derek's interview for more information.

Like with all the systems of the "Interton family", there are two controllers with 12 buttons keypad + 2 fire buttons + a joystick. Controllers were designed to use informative plastic layers delivered with each games, used to show the function of each key. The control panel is composed of an ON/OFF switch and 3 buttons (Reset program, Select Game, Start Game).  

____________

Thanks to David Elvin for most info

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> VIDEOMASTER DATABASE MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Database was first marketed by Videomaster, subsidiary of Waddington.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VIDEOMASTER DATABASE</strong></font><br><blockquote>... with Air Sea Battle cartridge inserted and plastic overlays placed on controllers<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUALITY TEST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here, in the Baldock factory, all consoles were tested one by one with a game. What is noteworthy is that the pinball game (available for the Interton VC-4000 for example) was never released for the Database.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOOSE PARTS...</strong></font><br><blockquote>...ready to be assembled in the Voltmace factory<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EMPLOYEES RESTING</strong></font><br><blockquote>...and drinking a cup of tea outside the Voltmace factory based in Baldock, UK.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASSEMBLY LINE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A technician is assembling the different parts of the Voltmace Database system together.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASSEMBLY LINE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Women assembling the different parts of the motherboard.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Elvin for this picture</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones for this picture.</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983 - The real-size system picture occupied almost the full right page. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>found on the system box</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This November 1982 advert introduces the new CoCo 1 price : $299 instead of $399.<br><br> Even if the advert said:<br><font color="#666666">"Hurry - this fantastic offer ends december 31, 1982" </font><br>the price never came back to $399.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl !  Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new revolutionnary modular system" <br><br> So you say... <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence" <br><br> Not less ! </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
